climbs.name: Wheel of Fortune
climbs.fa: Paul Schweizer, Randy Vogel, & Dave Evans, April 1986

content.description:
This route is found on the north end of Disneyland Dome; a crack leading to steep face on the obvious buttress.

Climb up a ramp and make a tricky move left into the easy appearing left slanting crack. This crack is steep, awkward and tricky (10d) and begins thin and finishes wide. Above the crack, make a circuitous journey on thin face climbing past 4 bolts (11b), eventually leading to a large ledge.

Rappel (100 feet) from a bolt anchor on the ledge.
content.protection: A variety of pro from thin up to 3+ inches for the crack, runners and 4 bolts.

climbs.name: Walt's Frozen Head
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines and Alf Randall, February 1988

content.description: One starts on a ledge about 40 ft right and around the corner of Brass Monkey.  Climb a short bit until one has to turn the corner and clip a bolt.  The climb then joins Brass Monkey at the top.
content.protection: A bit on the run side

content.description:
Start up and right of

Enchanted Stairway

below a darkly varnished face.

Climb the obvious crack system between

Enchanted Stairway

and

Brass Monkey

(the bolted line up the darkly varnished face) past a nolia to a belay ledge.
content.protection: Carry a standard JT rack with maybe a couple extra larger pieces.
content.location:
Start up and right of

Enchanted Stairway

below a darkly varnished face.

From the top of the route, move right and rappel with one rope from the anchors on

Never Grow Up

.

content.description:
Start about 50 feet uphill of

Snow White's Scary Adventures

in the notch between Disneyland Dome and Thrutcher Dome.

TR a thin seam/crack.
content.protection: Carry a standard JT rack to rig an anchor.
content.location:
Start about 50 feet uphill of

Snow White's Scary Adventures

in the notch between Disneyland Dome and Thrutcher Dome.

content.description:
Pitch 1: Climb out left on the

Mental Bankruptcy

dike to the belay at a block.

Pitch 2: Climb flakes above the belay, then go up and slightly left to a left facing corner. Follow the corner to the top.
content.protection:
Carry a standard rack.

From the top of P2, rappel 165 feet to the ground.
content.location:
Start at the first belay of

Mental Bankruptcy

on Disneyland Dome at a block.

climbs.name: Snow White's Scary Adventures
climbs.fa: Mike & Maura Veazey, Todd & Donette Swain 01-2017

content.description:
Begin a few feet uphill of

Peter Pan's Flight

and just downhill of a chasm.

Climb up a short flake to its top (red Camalot), then mantle onto a horizontal dike. Continue up a short, right facing flake (if you are tall, you can place a green Camalot in the flake) to easier ground.
content.protection:
Carry small to medium gear.

You can ultimately traverse left and rappel from the

Never Grow Up

anchor.
content.location:
Begin a few feet uphill of

Peter Pan's Flight

and just downhill of a chasm.

content.description:
Start about 20 feet uphill of

Never Never Land

at a short left-leaning ramp with a nolina growing out of its base. Just above the short ramp are two big flakes/blocks that are barely adhered to the wall.

Climb up and left to the top of the ramp, then climb the smooth face above to the top of the face.
content.protection:
Cams, small oak tree and cordelette for the anchor; can ultimately move left and rappel from the

Never Grow Up

anchor.
content.location:
Start about 20 feet uphill of

Never Never Land

at a short left-leaning ramp with a nolina growing out of it. Just above the short ramp are two big flakes/blocks that are barely adhered to the wall.

content.description: Make a somewhat strenuous traverse along a horizontal into a delicate flake to face above. Easily top-roped from the anchors above Never Grow Up. Two stars out of five.
content.location:
Located about 20' right of

Never Grow Up

.

climbs.name: Never Grow Up
climbs.fa: Chris Miller, Karen Roseme & Dave Carrera

content.description: Climb a crack/flake to three bolt face that leads directly to a bolted anchor/rap. One, maybe two stars out of five.
content.location:
Located on the east face of Disneyland Dome about 40' right of

Walt's Frozen Head

.

content.description:
Pitch 1: Climb out left on the

Mental Bankruptcy

dike to the first belay at a block.

Pitch 2: Move left about 20 feet to a finger crack. Climb up the crack then up and slightly left on the varnished face to the top.
content.protection:
Bolts, gear.

Rappel 165 feet to the ground from the top of P2.
content.location:
Starts out in the middle of

Mental Bankruptcy

on Disneyland Dome at the first belay stance at a block.

climbs.name: Mental Bankruptcy
climbs.fa: Charles Cole, Maria Cranor & Dan Leichtfuss, 1982

content.description: This route traverses most of the west face of Disneyland Dome via a thick band of protruding quartz. It starts near the southern end, a short scramble up and left of Jungle Cruise. As with most traverses, the follower faces the same dangers as the lead climber. The rock is somewhat gritty from a lack of traffic.
content.protection: Much of the climb is unprotected scrambling along a 4th class ledge. A light rack to 2" is useful for protecting the short crack at the start of pitch 1, and there is a good nut placement before the first bolt of pitch 2. All bolts are 3/8".

climbs.name: Mad Hatter, The
climbs.fa: Todd Swain and Dick Peterson, November 1989

content.description: Pitch 1 (5.10B) is sustained thin face climbing, protected by four bolts.  The crux is a short headwall at the top of the pitch.  Pitch 2 (5.9) follows a steep arete.  You can get good protection with RPs and stoppers.  To descend, scramble down a bit and rappel off the back side.  There is another Mad Hatter climb in Joshua Tree, on Hunk Rock near Barker Dam.
content.protection: standard rack, with four bolts on the first pitch
content.location: This is on the right side of the southwest face, to the right of the long dike of Mental Bankruptcy, and to the right of the chimney where Fantasia starts.

content.description:
Face climbing leads into the crack which varies from fingers to hands (crux) and then ends about 2/3 of the way up the face. After the crack ends move up and right on huge plates (5.6) to the ledge Enchanted Stairway ends on.

To descend head east towards Thrutcher Dome through a notch to reach rap anchors above the shorter east face - one rope easily makes it down.

A superb route which combines some fun crack climbing with runout but exhilarating face climbing, all in a semi-remote setting.
content.location:
Starts about 40' down and left from

Enchanted Stairway

below an obvious crack system that starts partway up the face.

content.description:
Start to the right of

Mental Bankruptcy

and

Autopia

at the obvious, left facing corner/chimney (the arête just right of this huge corner/chimney is the line of

the Mad Hatter

).

Pitch 1: Climb up the huge corner/chimney about 50 feet, then go left past a block to a belay at a right facing corner below the upper headwall.

Pitch 2: Climb the right facing corner then up to a bolt belay on a dike.

Pitch 3: Climb the crack directly above the belay (crux).
content.protection: Carry a standard JT rack with perhaps some additional big pieces for the initial corner/chimney.
content.location:
Start to the right of

Mental Bankruptcy

and

Autopia

at the obvious, left facing corner/chimney (the arête just right of this huge corner/chimney is the line of

the Mad Hatter

).

content.description:
This is the bolted route right of

Enchanted Stairway

on the nice steep dark colored rock.

climbs.name: Enchanted Stairway
climbs.fa: Mike Pope, Hank Levine & Russ Yeoman, December 1975  Direct: Brad Johnston, Bud Bruce, Randy Vogel & Mike Orr, January 1977

content.description: This was my second time leading a face climb at Joshua Tree, and it was exciting.  The first bolt is about 40 feet off the ground.  Just before you get to the first bolt you need to make a couple of 5.8 moves, including a high step/mantle on a small chicken head.  Before you make the moves to the first bolt, make sure to look down.  40 unprotected feet below your feet you will see a broken Manzanita bush and a cactus.  I wonder how the branches got broken?After the bolt comes a few nice 5.9 moves.  Then the climb gets easier on big patina flakes.  50 feet past the first bolt you will come to a second bolt.  Then about 60 more feet to the top.Definitely worth doing if you are a competentent 5.9 leader.  It is also perfect for a cold day because it faces the sun.
content.protection: There are two bolts on the route.  It is also possible to sling a couple of flakes/horns after the second bolt.

content.description:
This is a very loose and dangerous climb that should be avoided or top roped.

Climb up a steep chimney slot until possible to exit left on very loose face holds and steep hand crack.  Trying straight up looks more pleasant but quickly gets super hard.

Continue on very loose ground and creative gear placement to a half out 1/4" rawl drive bolt.  Spooge up heady steep face to reach a shallow crack that is better climbing.
content.protection: A helmet and face shield for belayer!  A light selection of TCU's and cams to 3".  Include gear that works on shallow flared loose grainy cracks.
content.location: This starts up the chimney above the start to the Mental Bankruptcy dike.
